In regard to this, nothing seems to me more equitable'
than that they who subscribe the largest amount to the roadl
should have the right of determining where it shall pass,!
Nor will I permit myself for a moment to believe that any]
delegate will refuse to lay aside all sectional feelings and'
persoal predilections for any particular lino of road. No? let!
us sacrifice on the altarof the general welfare,all local prefer,
ances and selfish interests, and unite in one generous cflbrlj
to promote the greatest good of the greatest number.
And now that, luckily for you, I have gone through all
the resolutions, and there arc not "a few more left" I corJ
elude as I commenced. I set out by declaring that I would!
not make a speech—1 will keep my promise, and close by]
respectfully declining to trespass on your time or patience]
by any remarks of mine. I move that the resolutions bel
adopted."
Mr. Cohen's remarks were listened to by the
Convention with profound attention, and received
much applause.
Mr. B. H. Payne moved the adoption of the
resolutions, which, after a long debate, in which
Hon. J. Moore, Mr. Sever, Mr. Lawrence, Mr. Forshey, Governor Mouton, and several other gentlemen, took part, was unanimously carried.
Mr. Lawrence proposed that no speaker occupy
the Convention more than fifteen minutes, or speak
more than once on one motion. Carried.
